Please check if you have the right permission on the serial terminal
/dev/ttyS0 may only be access by root.

Alternatively use gdbserver and TCP/IP
Reopen the PR, if still a problem

1. I don't have right permission on the serial terminal
/dev/ttyS0.
2. I just tried to debug localy (on Linux or Solaris) so I don't understand why 
(and how) I need to use gdbserver and TCP/IP.
3. Many times when I,or other people in my company, try to debug we just get 
the message "Failed luanching CDI Debugger" without any warning or log file. 
Because of this we can't debug on Linux or Solaris with Eclipse and it caused 
people to give up with Eclipse and to remain with their old IDEs!!
That's why this bug is so critical for us.

Make sure that the launch is set correctly, meaning that you
are not somehow try to debug serially 8-).

So go in the launch dialog:
 the little bug icon, drop down,
 choose "Debug ..."

Once the dialog pops:
 select your launch configuration and look at the tab "Debugger"
 in this tab there is a combo drop down:
   Debugger: - GDB Debugger
             - GDB Server

make sure the combo is on ___"GDB Debugger"__

if it is on "GDB Server" the default connection is "Serial"
and it will try to open "/dev/ttyS0".  To debug serial on GNU/Linux
you will have to change the permission of the device or
debug as root.

But according to your previous email you do not care about
serial debugging, in that case the Debugger should be "GDB Debugger".

If all that fails, send me the log trace of the MI debug session.

Maybe what's happening is when trying to create a
pseudo tty for debugging somehow it is returning "/dev/ttyS0" !!
At least that is my first guest.

Thanks

ping !!
This been mark as critical by the reporter.
Any feedbacks please ?

> org.eclipse.cdt.debug.core.cdi.CDIException: Error creating session: gdb: 
> unrecognized option `-i'

Try to run you version of gdb like this:

# gdb -i mi1 executable

If you have an error that means you have an old version of GDB.

Eclipse/CDT needs version gdb-5.2.x and above.

What does:

# gdb --version

reports ?

> This is a picture of the Debugger tab.
> It shows that only the GDB Server appears in the comboBox of Debugger 

It may means 
- that CDT did not find an executable that correspond
   to the local target.(are you doing cross-compiling ?)
- bad installation ?

What is your platform ?

Thanks for your answers.
About the picture - I understood why this had happened: The user had chosen to 
run a binary that is located on another machine (a binary of Solaris in Linux 
computer. So this is not a bug
About the gdb version - the version was 5.0.
I installed gdb6 and we are still checking it to see if the problem still 
exists.

> About the picture - I understood why this had happened: The user had chosen to 
> run a binary that is located on another machine (a binary of Solaris in Linux 
> computer. So this is not a bug

Good.

> About the gdb version - the version was 5.0.

Not good, if you try to start gdb like 

# gdb -i mi 1

it will probably fail.  And this his how CDT start the debugger.

> I installed gdb6 and we are still checking it to see if the problem still 
> exists.

I see no reason to keep this PR open.
Please make new PRs if you have problems with gdb-6.x
Again CDT need gdb version 5.2.1 and above to work.
